questions.text: Which DNA polymerase is primarily responsible for DNA repair in mammalian cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta

 

Option B:

 

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerase has 5 types: DNAP α, DNAP β, DNAP γ, DNAP δ, DNAP ε

 

 

Prokaryotic DNA Polymerase has 3 types: Pol I, Pol II and Pol III.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Alpha - DNA polymerase alpha is primarily involved in the initiation of DNA replication, particularly the synthesis of short RNA-DNA primers, rather than DNA repair.

 

Option C: Gamma - DNA polymerase gamma is responsible for the replication and repair of mitochondrial DNA, not nuclear DNA repair.

 

Option D: Epsilon - DNA polymerase epsilon is involved in leading-strand synthesis during DNA replication and also plays roles in DNA repair, but DNA polymerase beta is more specifically associated with the base excision repair pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA polymerase beta (β) plays a key role in the base excision repair (BER) pathway in mammalian cells, which is crucial for repairing small-scale DNA damage such as single-base lesions. This polymerase fills in the single-nucleotide gap left after the removal of a damaged base, contributing significantly to the maintenance of genomic stability.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 383.

questions.text: Match the following defective DNA repair processes to the corresponding disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 411.

questions.text: A gastroenterologist is evaluating a patient who has been diagnosed with multiple gastrointestinal polyps and carcinoma. The patient also has a significant family history of similar issues. Given this clinical presentation, the gastroenterologist is considering a genetic basis for the patient's condition that involves a defect in one of the DNA repair mechanisms. Which of the following DNA repair processes is most likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

 

Option A:

 

  • It is a case of Hereditary Polyposis Colon Cancer (Lynch syndrome).

  • Due to defect in hMSH1 and 2 genes in chromosome 2.

  • Mutation to the proteins involved in mismatch repair is associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC).

  • Only about 5% of all colon cancer results from mutations in mismatch repair.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP): Defective NER mechanism; sensitivity to UV light causing skin cancers.

 

Option C: MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP): Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER).

 

Option D: Bloom syndrome (BS), Werner syndrome (WS) etc: Defective Homologous Repair (HR).       

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Lippincott 6/e: p 411.

questions.text: A pediatric oncologist encounters a 6-year-old boy presenting with hyperpigmentation on his face, neck, forearms, and lower legs. The child's skin reddens and becomes painful upon sun exposure, and he develops blisters in these sun-exposed areas. Following a diagnosis of a skin tumor, the oncologist considers a genetic basis for the child's symptoms and sensitivity to sunlight. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nucleotide excision repair

 

Option B:

 

 

  • Xeroderma pigmentosa is the disorder in which nucleotide excision repair is defective, leading to accumulation of thymine dimers on exposure to UV rays → leads to skin cancer (SCC).

  • On examination - Presence of thickened, scaly areas (actinic keratosis) and hyperpigmented areas on skin exposed to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

  • Small, dilated blood vessels (telangiectasia) were also seen.

  • Treatment: Protection from sunlight - use of sunscreens and protective clothing that reflect UV radiation and chemicals that absorb it is also essential.

  • Also, frequent skin and eye examinations are recommended.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Thymine dimers (Incorrect): Nucleotide excision repair is defective, leading to accumulation of thymine dimers on exposure to UV rays.

 

Option C: Trinucleotide repeats (Incorrect): These are associated with diseases such as CGG repeat sequence - fragile X syndrome, CAG repeats - Huntington’s chorea, CTG -myotonic dystrophy and CAG in spinobulbar muscular atrophy.

 

Option D: Base alkylation (Incorrect): Single-base alteration → DNA damage → Base Excision Repair (BER)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a rare autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight. This condition typically arises from a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway, which is responsible for removing UV-induced DNA damage such as thymine dimers. Patients with XP have a high predisposition to develop skin tumors due to the accumulation of unrepaired DNA damage.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 412.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who has inherited one mutant allele of the BRCA1 gene has a 60% risk of developing breast cancer by age 50. The BRCA1 gene encodes a protein that plays a crucial role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Which DNA repair process is most likely impaired by a deficiency in BRCA1 protein function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Homologous recombination

 

Option D:

 

  • BRCA1 plays an important role in the repair of double-strand breaks.

  • Since homologous recombination requires a cleavage of both strands of a DNA molecule → deficiency of this gene/protein would affect the event of homologous recombination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Removal of thymine dimers: This is generally managed by nucleotide excision repair, not by homologous recombination.

 

Option B. Removal of RNA primers: RNA primers are removed during DNA replication, a process unrelated to the repair function of BRCA1.

 

Option C. Removal of carcinogen adducts: Like thymine dimers, carcinogen adducts are typically addressed by nucleotide excision repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 protein is fundamentally involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks primarily through homologous recombination, a critical process during cell division that ensures the accurate repair of DNA to prevent mutations that could lead to cancer. When BRCA1 function is compromised, the efficiency of homologous recombination repair is significantly reduced, which increases the risk of genomic instability and contributes to cancer predisposition, particularly breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  P 389-390.

choices.text: DNA repair of double strand breaks is error free.
DNA repair of mismatched bases repairs the parental strand.
Repair of uracil formed by deamination of cytosine need the actions of endo and exonucleases to remove the uracil base.
Repair of ultraviolet radiation–induced pyrimidine dimers formation involves removal of a short oligonucleotide sequence containing the dimer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describe DNA repair processes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Repair of ultraviolet radiation–induced pyrimidine dimers formation involves removal of a short oligonucleotide sequence containing the dimer

 

Option D:

 

Repair of DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) radiation involves the excision of a oligonucleotide with the dimer and replacing it is known as nucleotide excision repair.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: DNA repair of double strand breaks is error free (Incorrect): There is nothing like “error free’’ in DNA repair but the homologous -recombination method is less prone to error than the Non homologous–end-joining method.

 

Option B: DNA repair of mismatched bases repairs the parental strand (Incorrect): identification and repair of the newly synthesized strand.

 

Option C: Repair of uracil formed by deamination of cytosine need the actions of endo and exonucleases to remove the uracil base (Incorrect): Base excision repair: uracil is removed from DNA, utilizes a glycosylase to remove the base → forms an apyrimidinic or apurinic (AP) site → removal of sugar-phosphate by endo- and exonuclease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) is responsible for repairing bulky DNA lesions, such as pyrimidine dimers formed by ultraviolet radiation. NER involves the removal of a short single-stranded DNA segment that includes the dimer, followed by DNA synthesis using the intact strand as a template.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 390-392.

choices.text: Persons are sensitive to UV light
Cerebellar ataxia, oculo-cutaneous telangiectasia are clinical manifestations
Sunlight causes blisters on the skin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Xeroderma pigmentosum is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cerebellar ataxia, oculo-cutaneous telangiectasia are clinical manifestations

 

Option C:

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • Defect in nucleotide excision repair mechanism results in xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)
  • UV light (sunlight) → formation of thymine dimers → defective repair mechanism → accumulation of mutations → squamous cell carcinoma of skin.
  • Sensitivity to ultraviolet rays (sunlight) causes skin blisters.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: DNA repair is affected - This statement is correct. XP is caused by defects in the nucleotide excision repair mechanism, which is crucial for repairing UV-induced DNA damage.

 

Option B: Persons are sensitive to UV light - This is also correct. Individuals with XP have heightened sensitivity to UV radiation due to their inability to effectively repair UV-induced DNA damage.

 

Option D: Sunlight causes blisters on the skin - This is true for individuals with XP. Their heightened sensitivity to UV light can result in severe skin reactions, including blistering, even after minimal sun exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebellar ataxia and oculo-cutaneous telangiectasia are not typically clinical manifestations of Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP). These symptoms are more characteristic of disorders such as Ataxia-Telangiectasia (A-T). XP primarily involves sensitivity to UV light, leading to skin abnormalities such as blistering upon exposure to sunlight, due to a defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway that prevents the proper repair of UV-induced DNA damage.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 412.

choices.text: Homologous recombination requires a long homologous sequence to guide repair.
Non-homologous end-joining does not require a long homologous sequence to guide repair.
Homologous recombination repairs DNA before the cell enters mitosis.
Non-homologous end-joining repairs DNA after the cell enters mitosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about DNA double-strand breaks repair pathways is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-homologous end-joining repairs DNA after the cell enters mitosis.

 

Option D:

 

  • Double Strand Break Repair Mechanisms (DSB):  includes Homologous recombination (HR) and Non-homologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ).
  • Non-homologous end-joining repairs DNA before the cell enters mitosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Homologous recombination requires a long homologous sequence to guide repair - This is true. HR uses a homologous sequence, often from a sister chromatid, as a template to accurately repair the break.

 

Option B: Non-homologous end-joining does not require a long homologous sequence to guide repair - This is also true. NHEJ directly joins the broken DNA ends without needing a homologous template.

 

Option C: Homologous recombination repairs DNA before the cell enters mitosis - This is generally true. HR is most active in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle when a sister chromatid is available as a template for repair, ensuring accurate repair before the cell divides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 304-306

choices.text: Recognition, nicking, excision, replacement, and sealing
Nicking, excision, replacement, sealing, and recognition
Nicking, recognition, excision, sealing, and replacement
Nicking, sealing, recognition, excision, and replacement

questions.text: In a healthy individual without any defects in DNA repair pathways, gene repair mechanisms follow a precise sequence of events to maintain genomic integrity. A molecular biologist is explaining this sequence to a group of students, emphasizing the importance of each step in the process. Which of the following options correctly outlines the order of events in these gene repair mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A: Recognition, nicking, excision, replacement, and sealing

 

Option A:

 

In normal cells DNA repair happens in the following sequence of events:

 

The DNA is nicked on one side of the damaged DNA → a specific enzyme excises the damaged portion → damaged portion is replaced by resynthesis of new strand by DNA polymerase I → ligase seals the final gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA repair processes begins with the recognition of the DNA lesion, ensuring that the repair machinery can   differentiate damaged from undamaged DNA. Following recognition, a nick is introduced near the lesion to allow for the removal of the damaged segment (excision). The gap is then filled with the correct nucleotides (replacement), and finally, the DNA backbone is sealed (ligated), restoring the integrity of the DNA molecule.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 410-413.

choices.text: It is a Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)
Repair of replication errors such as bases mismatch is done

questions.text: Review the provided diagram of a DNA repair process and identify the incorrect statement concerning the pictured mechanism.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)          

 

Option B:

 

  • Mismatch repair (MMR)- Specific proteins do the scanning of newly synthesized DNA strand (new strand is not methylated) → mismatched area is identified and a loop is made.
  • In E. coli, such recognition and looping are done by three important proteins: MutS, MutC and MutH → mismatched segment is removed → correct segment is synthesized with the help of DNA polymerase and SSBs → sealed by ligase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It is a Mismatch Repair (MMR) - This statement is true based on the repair process shown in the diagram.

 

Option C: Repair of replication errors such as base mismatches is done - This is a correct statement as MMR is indeed responsible for repairing base mismatches that occur during DNA replication.

 

Option D: Defects result in Lynch syndrome - This is also true; defects in MMR can cause Lynch syndrome (Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer), which is characterized by a higher risk of developing colorectal cancer and other cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA repair process involving the recognition and removal of a base mismatch, which is characteristic of Mismatch Repair (MMR), not Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER). MMR corrects errors that escape proofreading during DNA replication, such as base mismatches or insertion/deletion loops.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 389, 390.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary effect of UV light damage to the DNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Formation of pyrimidine dimers

 

Option A:

 

UV light exposure primarily leads to the formation of pyrimidine dimers, specifically thymine dimers, in DNA. These dimers result from the covalent bonding between adjacent pyrimidine bases on the same DNA strand, distorting the DNA structure and potentially leading to errors during DNA replication and transcription if not repaired.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: No damage to DNA - This is incorrect as UV light is well-documented to cause DNA damage, particularly the formation of pyrimidine dimers.

 

Option C: DNA hydrolysis - UV light does not typically cause DNA hydrolysis. Hydrolytic DNA damage is more often associated with chemical and water-mediated reactions.

 

Option D: Double stranded breaks - While UV light can lead to various types of DNA damage, it is most known for causing pyrimidine dimers rather than double-stranded breaks, which are more commonly associated with ionizing radiation and certain chemicals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA lesions formed by UV light damage includes Bulky adducts and Pyrimidine Dimers.

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 390.
